Context:
Program Name: Child and Youth Care (Accelerated)
Code: C153
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 12 consecutive months
Starting Months: May
Domestic Tuition: $3,707.00 *
International Tuition: $17,838.00 **
Location: St. James Campus
Program Description: The program will teach skills to work effectively with children, youth, and families experiencing social, emotional, developmental, and behavioural challenges. Open for international students in the Spring semester of 2025 with an open application period starting Aug 6, 2024.
Accreditation: Nationally accredited by the Child and Youth Care Educational Accreditation Board of Canada
Program Outcomes: Develop therapeutic skills and abilities to support at-risk children, youth, and families. Collaborate with professional teams and build therapeutic relationships with clients.
Related Programs: Child and Youth Care (C133), Social Service Worker (Accelerated) (C135), Social Service Worker (C119)
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Child and Youth Care Program (Accelerated) C153 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The accelerated Child and Youth Care (CYC) program is a condensed version of the three-year CYC program, delivered over 12 consecutive months in three semesters. Students are required to complete a Ministry-approved crisis prevention and intervention training certificate in their third semester. The program offers two field placement opportunities: one seven-week placement during the summer semester and another four-month placement during the winter semester, each placement being four days a week. Field placements take place in various settings within the Greater Toronto Area (GTA) such as group homes, educational settings, hospitals, youth shelters, schools, after-school programs, community outreach programs, and youth justice. Students are expected to work day and evening shifts and may be requested to work on weekends. Graduates are eligible for membership in the Ontario Association of Child and Youth Counsellors (OACYC). The program starts in May.

Additional Information:
- CYC students will learn how to build therapeutic relationships with clients and collaborate with a professional team.
- Students will assess risk and developmental needs of vulnerable children and families, design and implement therapeutic intervention, and crisis intervention and safety planning.
- Students will be required to work in multiple small and large groups within classes and community settings.
- International placement experiences are available when possible.
- Career options for graduates include membership in the Ontario Association of Child and Youth Counsellors (OACYC).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Child and Youth Care Program (Accelerated) C153 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text is about a Child and Youth Care (Accelerated) (C153) program offered at George Brown College in Ontario, Canada. The graduates of this program may find employment in various sectors such as treatment centres, group homes, hospitals, youth shelters, schools, after-school programs, community-based treatment programs, and youth justice.

The graduates are also eligible to apply for advanced standing in other programs at different universities like Toronto Metropolitan University, Humber College, University of Victoria in British Columbia, and Trent University. They can also apply for advanced standing in specific degree programs such as B.A. Health/Community in the School of Public Health and Social Policy, B.A. Justice Studies, and B.A. Professional Communication at Royal Roads University.

The required courses for this program are spread across six semesters with specific codes and names mentioned for each course. Some of the courses include Therapeutic Activities (CYCS 1048), Counselling Children and Youth (CYCS 1049), Human Sexuality (CYCS 2042), Equity, Inclusion and Anti-Oppressive Practices (CYCS 1055), Trauma-Informed Approaches (CYCS 2026), Mental Health in Child and Youth Care (CYCS 3017), Community-Based Practices (CYCS 3020), Crisis Prevention and Intervention (BST 2003).

Therefore, the extracted information is as follows:

* George Brown College offers a Child and Youth Care (Accelerated) (C153) program.
* Graduates may find employment in various sectors including treatment centres, group homes, hospitals, youth shelters, schools, after-school programs, community-based treatment programs, and youth justice.
* They are eligible to apply for advanced standing in other programs at Toronto Metropolitan University, Humber College, University of Victoria, and Trent University.
* Specific degree programs they can apply for include B.A. Health/Community in the School of Public Health and Social Policy, B.A. Justice Studies, and B.A. Professional Communication at Royal Roads University.
* Required courses for this program are spread across six semesters with specific codes and names mentioned for each course. Some of the courses include Therapeutic Activities (CYCS 1048), Counselling Children and Youth (CYCS 1049), Human Sexuality (CYCS 2042), Equity, Inclusion and Anti-Oppressive Practices (CYCS 1055), Trauma-Informed Approaches (CYCS 2026), Mental Health in Child and Youth Care (CYCS 3017), Community-Based Practices (CYCS 3020), Crisis Prevention and Intervention (BST 2003).

Context:
SEMESTER 6 Courses:
- CYCS 2011: Writing for the Profession
- CYCS 2035: Fieldwork Seminar II
- CYCS 3016: Working with Families
- CYCS 3018: Field Practice II

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Develop and maintain therapeutic relationships with children, youth and their families
- Assess the strengths, developmental and holistic needs of children, youth and their families
- Develop and implement care and intervention plans appropriate for the therapeutic milieu
- Use equitable and inclusive approaches that are anti-colonial, anti-oppressive, anti-racist, and strength-based frameworks
- Advocate for, and in solidarity with, children, youth, their families and communities
- Employ communication, collaboration and relational skills with the inter-professional team and community partners
- Engage in self-inquiry, relational inquiry and critical reflection
- Use professional development resources and supervision
- Adhere to relevant legislation and Child and Youth Care standards of practice
- Practice in a variety of contexts and settings
- Employ crisis prevention and intervention techniques

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $3,707.00
- International Tuition: $17,838.00
* Amounts listed are the estimated total of tuition, materials, student service, and ancillary fees

Context: The text provides information about the estimated tuition, materials, student service, and ancillary fees for programs starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024 at George Brown College. The fees are subject to change and do not include books, which are to be purchased separately by students. International students should refer to specific pages for additional information on fees and admission requirements. Financial assistance is available for approved applicants through OSAP, but students are responsible for verifying fee requirements. Applicants with international transcripts who do not provide English proficiency test results must complete an English assessment at the college. Course exemptions may be granted based on previously earned college or university credits, and students will need to meet mandatory Pre-placement requirements upon acceptance into some programs, which include providing medical records, proof of a Vulnerable Sector Check, a Standard First Aid Certificate and CPR level C certificate, and an annual flu shot. The text also mentions that tuition fees are subject to board approval and that all fees are subject to change without notice. There is no specific mention of the program name or location in the text.

Context:
The text relates to health and non-academic requirements for students in a program at the college. Here are the key factual points extracted from the text:

1. First Aid Certificate and CPR level C must be renewed every three years and annual flu shots submitted by the program-specific deadline to ParaMed Placement Pass website.
2. COVID-19 vaccination is required for students working with vulnerable communities and clinical agency partners. Students who are not vaccinated may not be able to complete their clinical placement course requirements.
3. Students are responsible for all costs, service fees, and fines associated with the overall health requirements.
4. Mandatory Pre-placement health form can be downloaded from the Clinical Pre-placement website.
5. Vulnerable Sector Check is required for students in the program, and it must be renewed every six months before entering into the field or clinical placement.
6. The Vulnerable Sector Check process typically takes two to three months but can take four to eight months.
7. Students are responsible for ensuring that the Vulnerable Sector Check covers appropriateness for individuals working with vulnerable persons.
8. Students are required to keep the original copy of their Vulnerable Sector Check.
9. Students who cannot provide a clear Vulnerable Sector Check will not be able to start their field or clinical placement and will therefore be unable to complete the program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Child and Youth Care Program (Accelerated) C153 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:

It mentions that not meeting the requirements for field placement can prevent students from completing the program or securing employment. International students are encouraged to contact the International Centre for more information.

The text also mentions that there is an Information Session for interested individuals to learn more about the program, meet professors, and have questions answered. The text provides related programs at George Brown College: Child and Youth Care (C133), Social Service Worker (Accelerated) (C135), and Social Service Worker (C119).
